0jfziD4HY6xwCE0FKfO0.CodebaseRequirements: The developer should know where the metal image processing pipeline exists in the codebase
0jfziD4HY6xwCE0FKfO0.Defect: Using a Metal backed core image context to render to a MTKView
0jfziD4HY6xwCE0FKfO0.KnowledgeRequirements: The developer should have basic knowledge about the high level structures provided by Metal and how they work. This includes: the Metal Device, Command Queue, Command Buffers, and Render Encoders.
0jfziD4HY6xwCE0FKfO0.StrategyDefenition:
#Apple has recently moved to using the Metal programming language for GPU programming on iOS, replacing CoreImage and OpenGL.
#While Metal offers many good features, sometimes it is quicker to use image processing features that have already been written
#using CoreImage instead of taking the time to rewrite them in Metal. Apple provides an MTKView as a solution for easily rendering
#Metal backed content to a view. This Strategy helps you to use CoreImage to render to a MTKView on iOS.

#Required Tools and Environment
- Assuming XCode is already installed on the system, project is checked out,
and successfully building/running.
- Assuming a Metal backed image processing pipeline has already been set up 
in the project

#Required Knowledge
- basic knowlege of Metal and CoreImage on iOS
- experience with Swift or Objective-C 

STRATEGY useCoreImageToRenderToMetalView()
    #create a CoreImage Context using the Metal device
    Find where the Metal device is being created in the project
    IF a CoreImage Context has not already been created
        Immediately after creating the metal device, create a CoreImage Context, passing the device in as the parameter
    #verify the MTKView is framebufferOnly propety configured properly
    IF the MTKView's framebufferOnly property is not set OR the MTKViews framebufferOnly property == TRUE
        #this is a very important step as it allows a CIImage to be written directly 
        #to the MTKView's texture. Otherwise, the output will display a solid purple/pink color.
        set the MTKView's framebufferOnly property to FALSE
    #A new command buffer will be created on each render pass 
    Create a new command buffer using the Metal device's command queue
    Create a new CIImage from the given pixel buffer you would like to render
    #apply whatever CIFilters you would like to use on the CIImage (one after another)
    FOR EACH 'filter' IN 'CIFilters'
        DO applyFilter(CIImage)
    #after the filters have been applied to the CIImage, render the CIImage to the MTKView
    Use the CoreImage Context created earlier to render the CIImage directly to the MTKView's current drawable
    #submit the command buffer to be executed by the GPU
    Present the command buffer 
    Commit the commmand buffer
    RETURN nothing
0jfziD4HY6xwCE0FKfO0.ToolsRequirements: Mac computer, XCode, an iPhone device to run the code on

CommonDifficulties.ConcentrationDifficulty:: Not really because I had to think about the scenarios I run into and then try to write something which is generic enough without knowing the problem. However, there may be issues where you really have to concentrate to write down a proper strategy.
CommonDifficulties.GuidelinesSupportDifficulty::
It gives it a standardized and structured format which could be easier for any developer to follow. They need to be familiar with some programming style though. 
For example, a developer who mainly works with HTML and CSS may not quickly grasp the syntaxes and format mentioned for Roboto strategy.
CommonDifficulties.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty ::
It's a bit hard because there may be multiple ways to troubleshoot and debug an issue and some general strategy may not give an accurate way of diagnosing a problem. 
Also, a part of strategy could be to ask the question to a novice developer about the problem to come up with a proper strategy.
CommonDifficulties.RobotoSupportDifficulty:: For the most part, yes, but there might be something that it's missing. For example, I didn't see anything about ELSE condition along with IF
CommonDifficulties.TimeConsumptionDifficulty:: It takes time to write something down in a proper, strucutured format over just talking to someone or even writing it down based on the exact issue.
CommonDifficulties.TranslationDifficulty: It's not hard to translate thoughts and strategies into works but also it's not easy either. It's much easier if it's done in person or you are talking to that person over writing it down.

OtherDifficulties:
I didn't see if Roboto supports ELSE conditions so I think that would be helpful. 
Having something like tagging an action could be beneficial. E.g. if you tag a specific line or action with something, you can reference that tag somewhere else in the strategy. The concept may be similar to Calls but there's no function or sub-strategy in there
Maybe having something like GOTO could be helpful in instances where you want the user to go to a specific line in the strategy, it could use tag name to point the user to
Auth1.StrategyDefinition:
# This strategy is to troubleshoot and debug CSS issues on a web page where appropriate styling is not being applied on an element

# Required Knowledge

Basic HTML knowledge

Basic CSS knowledge

Basic familiarity with broswer dev tools



#Required Tools and Environments

#Any of the modern browsers would work: Chrome, Firefox, IE Edge, Safari as all come with dev tools these days

#For this strategy I am going to go with Chrome but the strategy applies to other browsers as well

Chrome or Firefox

#IDE environment like Visual Studio Code, Brackets, Notepad++

#For this strategy, I am going to consider Notepad++



STRATEGY DebugCSS()


#Open the web page in your browser where you have CSS issue


Open web page in Chrome


SET 'wrongCSSElements' to the elements that have wrong styling applied


FOR EACH 'wrongCSSElement' IN 'wrongCSSElements'



Right-click on the element that doesn't have the right styling 



Click on "Inspect Element"



#This will open the chrome dev tools either on the side or in the bottom by default



This shows Chrome developer tools 



The element will be highlighted in there



# Left side shows HTML and right side shows the styling for that element



On the right side, it shows the styling applied to that element



# Sometimes the wrong styling is coming from an element's parent or something defined at a global level



IF you see the incorrect styling in there




Change it in the dev tools to see the changes in your browser in real-time



ELSE 




scroll down to other styles to identify the style that is overwriting the right style




Change it in the dev tools to see the changes in your browser in real-time



#The site could be using multiple css files, dev tools shows the CSS file name where the style comes from



Check the CSS file where the wrong style is coming from



Open the CSS file in Notepad++



Find the CSS class in this file and update it




RETURN nothing

WorkExperiences.background: I am a full stack developer with an experience of over 8 years. For back-end, I am proficient with ASP.NET and SQL DB.
WorkExperiences.biggestSoftware:
Created an application that syncs the user data and their permissions to access the website between the CMS, Database and Salesforce. The application and its features were role and access based, so depending on the roles of a user and permissions set on the pages, a user will have access to. A user has to pay to get access to different roles, so it is very critical that they have access to only what is required, and shouldn't be able to access other stuff. 
The application runs through all users and ensures everything is in sync and also logs everything with timestamp.
WorkExperiences.biggestWebApplication:
We got new conference registration vendor which handles conference logistics and registration. They should check if a user already exists in the database, if not, it reates their record and order in the vendor database, and should do the same in our systems. 
I created APIs for them to check if a user exists, create users, create orders, apply payment records etc, along with some detailed logging to create reports to be analyzed later to ensure the integration worked well.

CommonDifficulties.ConcentrationDifficulty:: I spent far more 45 minutes to write this strategy, although generally speaking, css debugging is amongst the easiest ones
CommonDifficulties.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty :: Some general concepts can be strategized, but development comes with some unexpected outcomes that it is hard to write strategies when outcome is unexpected
CommonDifficulties.RobotoSupportDifficulty:: It is a new idea and it can be effective. Roboto language can make it more opinionated to write strategies. It is some kind of standardizing for writing strategies.
CommonDifficulties.StrategyEndingDifficulty:: I don't think so, It is like writing a program. every good programmer comes with a plan how to wire its code. programming strategies is no exception.
CommonDifficulties.TimeConsumptionDifficulty:: It is tiring because you need to check if you have included all the cases could happen
CommonDifficulties.TranslationDifficulty: Some edge cases is hard to include in a strategy as a general recipe. Also, sometimes you need to show a demo or some sort of an example to make your point.

OtherDifficulties: When going through tutorials about how to use Roboto, I found it difficult when a statement is finished (I mean, some times I thought the statement sentence is just wrapped to the next line, because not enough space was there). Maybe if you could add some sort of line termination like semicolon ";" or just period ".", since the statement will be read by humans.
Auth13.StrategyDefinition:
# This Strategy helps developer fix the issue of an element with undesired visual/position style.
#Required Tool and Environment
Web Browser(Google chrome is preferred)
#Required Knowledge
Basic Knowledge of css and html
STRATEGY DebugCss()
    Open your web app and go to the page with undesired element
    SET 'buggedElement' TO element with undesired style and positioning
    # The "inspect" action name might be different from Browser to Browser
    Right click on 'buggedElement' and click on inspect
    # An extra window opens with some tabs like Element, Console and Styles
    Click on Styles tab in the inspect window
    # Make sure your buggedElement is highlighted or chosen
    # you will be able to see a list of stylings applied to element
    IF 'buggedElement' has issue when hovering or focusin on it
        # When clicking on :hov, few checkboxes appears
        # :hover, :focus, :active  are amongst them
        Click on ":hov" and check all the boxes that applies
    
    IF 'buggedElement' issue is positioning
        SET 'position' TO 'buggedElement' position proptery value
        IF 'position' is not absolute
            DO FixCss('buggedElement')
            RETURN nothing
        
        # element with position absolute is positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor
        # Note: A "positioned" element is one whose position is anything except static.
        IF 'position' is absolute
            # desired parent means the parent element that buggedElement was supposed to be relative to
            Look up at element's ancestors and find the desired parent
            SET 'parent' TO desired parent element
            Change the 'parent' position proptery to relative
            RETURN nothing
    
    IF 'buggedElement' issue is styling
        DO FixCss('buggedElement')
        RETURN nothing

STRATEGY FixCss(buggedElement)
    # You can use filter input to search for it
        # Or you can scroll through the styles manually
        Search through the stylings to find where it gets its undesired value
        SET 'undesiredStyling' TO the line number and css file found in the search
        IF 'undesiredStyling' is not found
            # You will find all stylings applied to the element here
            # Once you found the stylings you were looking for
            # You can click small arrow to jump to the place it gets its value
            Click on Computed tab and use filter to search
            SET 'undesiredStyling' TO line number found here
        SET 'perfectStyleList' TO an empty list of css properties
        UNTIL buggedElement has desired styling
            # you can add or change different css styles to the element
            # it then applies instantly to element stylings
            Use element.Style to apply css to buggedElement
            add the style proptery to 'perfectStyleList'
        DO ApplyCssToElement(buggedElement, 'perfectStyleList')
      
STRATEGY ApplyCssToElement(element, style)
    # Css rules are cascading. The one with most priority applies
    # This is how priority gets evaluated
    # !important |  style="" | id selector | class attribute, psudo class selector | type selector and psudo element
    # For easy explanation: use this url: http://qnimate.com/dive-into-css-specificity/
    # Also the if there are two css files having the same selector, the file placed last in order is evaluated
    IF style has to be applied to only this element
        # e.g. choose last css file in order, use id selector and so on
        Use strogest selector, apply style to element
        RETURN nothing
    IF style has to be applied on many elements
        use class selector, apply style to element
        RETURN nothing

Auth5.StrategyDefinition:
#This Strategy helps you learn how to utilize the Chrome Profiler

#in order to identify slow or inefficient components

#Requried Tools and Environments

Chrome

A Web Application

#Requried Knowledge

Chrome

CPU managment

Web Applications

CSS

HTML

Components to Test



Strategy ProfileComponent()

    #Open your chosen web appliation in the Chrome Browser

    Open the Chrome Browser

    Navigate to your Web Application

    Right Click and select 'Inspect'

    Click on the Performace Tab

    Click the Record Button as indicated

    Perform Task on the web application utilizing the component

    Click Stop

    #A peak is a section of the flame chart where CPU is high

    IF there are peaks in the flame chart

        FOR EACH peak

            Click on the peak

            Drag your mouse to highlight the entire peak

            Hover over the NET section to view the CSS component utilized

            Click on the Event Log in the bottom

            Select the longest Task

            Expand the Task

            Click on the Function Call to identify the component

            Look at the current frame state, network requests, animations in 

                order to come to a conclusion of why the component is slow

RETURN NOTHING

I left that position after 2 years because I enjoyed coding more than managing and also felt like I was more valuable as a developer.

Features included uploading news stories, commenting, live chatting as well as image uploads, video uploads and mapping. The application had a search feature as well. CommonDifficulties.ConcentrationDifficulty::
It needs an understanding of the problems. Asking 3 core questions in any strategies. Why What and How.
Concentration to keep the key points. The effort to make sure all the use cases are addresses and energy to keep the team going.
CommonDifficulties.GuidelinesSupportDifficulty:: Yes. Always. The issue comes in once it's done its challenging to keep on the path.
CommonDifficulties.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty :: Depends on novice developer, who is working with. Tools are mere tools, the way we think it counts.
CommonDifficulties.RobotoSupportDifficulty::
Every strategy for each problem, business is different. The way we address issues depending on experience is different. 
Yes to help with organizing strategy would be nice. With apps to do everything like Jira, AHA, Google sheets its good to have a common tool to manage ideas. Would be good to have toolkit or template handy to begun strategizing issues.
CommonDifficulties.StrategyEndingDifficulty:: Depends on the tram, business goals, financial impact, leadership vision. It can be hard as it happens in many startup or organization with new ideas but it makes us better for next challenge.
CommonDifficulties.TimeConsumptionDifficulty:: No, it's not. It helps to communicate problems more clearly. Shows experience, makes us think out of box.
CommonDifficulties.TranslationDifficulty: So many tools are available to translate thoughts into words. Using flow diagrams, sketches or even list of tasks can do the job. More we understand and dissect the problems more easy or efficient it is to solve.

OtherDifficulties: This is a very common issue within any organization. Any strategy is a simple path to solve a specific problem, not a solution to solve a problem.

CommonDifficulties.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty :: It's hard, but it's doable. The key is to put yourself in their shoes and keep reminding yourself of the audience. It also helps to visualize the novice developer and think about what's the first question he's going to ask when he sees this.
CommonDifficulties.RobotoSupportDifficulty:: The Roboto syntax as a concept seems very useful. Developers of all experience levels frequently leave out important items like context or environment. However, I did not find the formatted examples to be readable or easy to understand, and the box where I was supposed to enter my own strategy was even more unreadable/unusable since using the Roboto syntax did not trigger any type of conditional color coding or formatting. Eventually I abandoned Roboto because it was taking focus away from the strategy
CommonDifficulties.StrategyEndingDifficulty:: I wasn't sure whether to include testing or not.
CommonDifficulties.TimeConsumptionDifficulty:: It's not boring, but it can be very, very time consuming. I spent over an hour on this and I'm still not very happy with it.
CommonDifficulties.TranslationDifficulty: It's hard to put them into writing

OtherDifficulties: There is no way I could complete the assignment in 45 minutes.
The text box for entry had no line wrapping, but the Roboto syntax guidelines did not specify a syntax for line breaks
Auth7.StrategyDefinition:
# This Strategy will guide you to identifying types of error that a front end component may need to handle



#Required Tools and Environments

Ongoing software project with separate frontend and backend tiers, such as a Model-View-Controller architecture

Installed IDE appropriate for chosen front end technology

The software application can be compiled and executed



#Required Knowledge

Knowledge of error handling for chosen front end language

Knowledge of the calls that will be made to the backend

Knowledge of the expected responses from the backend



#Context

You understand the intended behavior of your UI component and the overall application.

Now I want you to assume that the backend is completely out of your control, and will not behave the way you expect.



STRATEGY FrontEndErrorHandling()

    First, you want to break down the different types of failures

    You should consider all of the following scenarios, and build a list of errors

    

    IF no response ever returns

        Identify how long your front end will wait for a response, and where this is defined

        

        IF the timeout is not defined in a central, configurable location

            Code: Move the timeout value to a central, configurable location



        To make this testable, shorten the timeout to a very short duration



        Execute the application and force a timeout. What happens?



        Code: Add Error Handling for the timeout

        SET 'errorList' TO this error



    IF a NULL or empty response is returned

        Code: Add checks for null or empty objects before attempting to use them



        IF null or empty is a valid response in this context

            Code: Ignore the error and gracefully render an empty UI control



        IF null or empty is not valid

            Code: Add error handling

            SET 'errorList' TO this error



    IF the wrong response is returned

        Consider what the "right" response means



            Make a list of rules that defines the expected response

            #Examples: Size, Data Type, Number of Items



            Code: Add error handling for a violation of each rule

            # This does not always mean a failure. You will need to decide on context whether to stop the application here, or proceed



            IF this is a failure

                SET 'errorList' TO this error



        IF Data returned does not match the type expected



            Code: Add error handling and abort

            SET 'errorList' TO this error



        IF there are differences in syntax or casing between the frontend and backend system

            Code: Implement checks to detect and convert the syntax or casing

            # Example: converstion between Pascal case and camel case



            IF there is no universal conversion possible, and it's possible for conversion to fail

                # Universal conversion would mean that any difference can be transformed based on the syntax or casing, not on hard coded exact matches of strings/properties

                

                Code: Add error handing and abort

                SET 'errorList' TO this error



        IF some data is missing

            Code: Set default values for missing fields



            IF the component depends on these fields to render or function

                Code: Add error handling and abort

                SET 'errorList' TO this error



    FOR EACH 'error' in 'errorList'

    

        DO IF the UI component cannot be rendered and an error message needs to be displayed

            Write user-friendly error messages, including any instructions to recover from the error

            Centralize your list of error messages

            Present them to the user within a single component



        DO Run the application to test the error handling for this error

        # If you are not able to recreate a particular failure situation, that does not mean it cannot happen!

        # You may need the assistance of a backend developer to truly test these, but that's a differe Strategy...



RETURN nothing

Information Technology and M.S. Software Engineering) were in Java, moving into web applications with JSP, JSF, etc. Professionally, I primarily work in C# and .NET Microsoft applications environments, while also utilizing Angular.

I have moved from role to role within the team depending on needs and release schedule, from database development to back end development to front end development. I am now the technical subject matter expert for the application's business processes, workflows, and user experiences.

CommonDifficulties.GuidelinesSupportDifficulty:: Yes having an SOP is very helpful for knowledge transfer.
CommonDifficulties.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty :: Using screen shots helps with beginners
CommonDifficulties.RobotoSupportDifficulty:: I need to get used to it
CommonDifficulties.StrategyEndingDifficulty:: All strategies are an endless WIP as they are never "complete"
CommonDifficulties.TimeConsumptionDifficulty:: Yes, but it helps in the long run.
CommonDifficulties.TranslationDifficulty: I write SOP documents often so I am used to this sort of thing

Auth9.StrategyDefinition:
# This Strategy helps impliment error handling for a web application

#Considerations

User input

Database Errors 

#Required Knowledge

Web application language

Database SQL



STRATEGY UserInput()

# Goal is to limit free-hand input and use strong typing

Use list-boxes as much as possible

Use Try-Catch and log errors

IF list-boxes cannot be used, validate textboxes

    Validate datatypes for all enteries

    IF numberic reject alpha

    IF date validate dates and reject invalid dates

    IF character Check for injection (SQL and script) AND

       Check for spcial characters

    FOR EACH 'textbox' On Page

        Validate



    IF Error Found    

       RETURN Error 

    ELSE

       Submit Page



STRATEGY Database()

# Handle null values, data truncation, invalid datatypes

In Queries check values before performing Substring functions

Use stored procedures to limit SQL injection

Use IsNull (or NVL) for nulls. 

Check for blank values using len(trim(<columnName>)) = 0

DO NOT USE "where 1 = 1" in queries as this allows for 

SQL injection

Use Try-Catch and log all errors

WorkExperiences.background:
Full stack web developer. Currently using SQL Server and C#.

www.linkedin.com/in/thoraya-zedan-0576692
WorkExperiences.biggestSoftware: I do not write industrial software
WorkExperiences.biggestWebApplication: Application used by the Department of State for all software acquisitions

Difficulties: How to test if my strategy is understandable by other human. It would be nice if there is a tool that check for ambiguity.

In general, would like to see a better tool support. writing text without like autocomplete and refactoring tools is a bit boring. I feel if the editor has better support for strategies authoring, I would enjoy writing long strategies.
Writing comment vs statement was always a challenge. I guess to what extend my strategy should be abstract and explained by comments vs having more explicitly statements with less comments?
Pilot2.StrategyDefinition:
#This Strategy helps you identify bottleneck  in your web application.



#Required Tools and Environments

Chrome web browser

A JavaScript project

#Required Knowledge

Basic knowledge of how to use Chrome DevTools

Basic knowledge of javaScript



STRATEGY performanceProfiler()

# You need to first identify potential line of code

# that might cause the performance overhead.

# Look at data structures for any memory leaks

# Look at loops and the code inside them.

# Look at third party APIs calls.



Hypothesize where in your code the bottleneck are

Set 'suspectLines' To the line of code that might cause the bottleneck 



For EACH line in 'suspectLines'

    # Add large numbers to data structures

    # Make the loop execute thousands of time

    # Call that third-party API hundreds of time

    # If  you do so, you do not need to execute your code for long time

    # so that the memory leak surfaces or the bottleneck is obvious  

    Amplify line impact



Set 'randomLine' to random line of code that IS NOT IN 'suspectLines'

For EACH line in 'randomLine'

# These lines are your baseline for how should the code work

# Make sure that you set similar values to that 

# you set to 'suspectLine'  

    Amplify line impact



#Lood your javaScript through the Chrome web browser

#Open up the Chrome DevTools and head to the profiler

# Run the application and wait until all the code execute

Run the web application through google DevTools



For EACH line in 'suspectLines'



    #check how the code you suspect is the problem is acting comparing to 

    #the code that you are pretty sure has nothing to do 

    #with the performance issue

    check their CPU time and Memory usage and compare to the similar line in randomLine



    IF the line in 'suspectLines' has more overhead than the line in 'randomLine'

        Fix

RETURN nothing

Difficulties: the strategy itself is complex: debugging performance issues requires checking multiple interdependent representations of the program.

comparing results makes it hard to describe the strategy or navigate back to a previous step makes it is hard to summarize: If I have to replicate the same strategy with some code change in order to check wether it is faulty or not and the continue the strategy. This means I have to create a main strategy and rewrite the current one to support multiple input and finally use them as a step for the main one.

I realized I have to use variables while setting conditionals: several times I wrote the conditional and realize that it depended on something else. How do I know that conditional tests may be need to be reused later thus requiring refactoring the code
Pilot3.StrategyDefinition:
#Required Tools and Environments
Browser Performance Profiler
Performance problem example
#Required Knowledge
Understandinng of memory leaks, CPU performance hotspot, and chart analysis
STRATEGY findPerformanceHotSpot()
    Load web application
    IF perfomance dive is observable at load time
        # perhaps is not CPU related
        observe Network Profiler for unusual load times for app's libraries
    ELSE
       excercise UI to replicate slowdown
       IF UI actions triggers slowdown
            go to Performance tab and find frame that matches the slowdown actions
            Find timestamp for action start and end, and narrow down the timeline analysis window
            Look at the interaction tab and analyze the call stack
            Inspect for unusual calls in the stackframe
            IF unusual call behavior found
                go to responsible code and comment
                repeat this process and compare results
            ELSE
                Inspect Unexpectedly long calls in the stackframe 
                or Event Log where rendering type activities take more time than expected
                IF unusual rendering behavior found
                    go to responsible code and comment
                    repeat this process and compare results
                    ELSE
                     Try frames before the current one to backtrack the fault and repeat from this STRATEGY from the begining

Difficulties: I did not understand Roboto preconditions. Some of them were repetitive, so I was not sure which terms to actually use.
Pictures tell a thousand words. There should be an easy way to capture screenshots for such profiling tasks instead of writing them down and hoping the person will understand.
I dont know how much of a good job I did here, because there are already good resources from Google about using its Profiler. What did you expect me to do more?
What does react (below) have to do with this strategy? I thought it was about Chrome profiler not react.

If the task is about web development, I expect the example to reflect a similar task. Otherwise, it is difficult for me to really understand the level of detail you expect of me. Particularly, profiling is not same as Git merge. Git merge is not that simple (as in example) because you left a lot of steps that could possibly have gone wrong. Point is they both are difficult in their own ways, so I really did not get much by reading Git merge task for me to use it as reference for the Profiling task.
Pilot4.StrategyDefinition:
#Required tools and environment
Chrome/Chromium Browser

#Required knowledge
HTML tags
JS/CSS proficiency: professional

STRATEGY Profile()
    Open the webpage that you want to profile.
    Open DevTools and navigate to the Performance tab.
    Comprehend the actions you want to profile.
    IF you want to only profile the page load time
        Click on the "Start Profiling and reload page" button.
        # Profiling will stop few seconds after page load.
        Wait for profiling to finish.
    ELSE
        Click on the "Start Profiling button"
        Perform your actions and click "Stop" when done
    # Each event is a rectangle box. Scrolling should zoom in and out
    Observe that the profiler produces a graph of events captured
    # Top right red corners indicate events with potential performance issues
    SET 'problems' TO events with red top right corners 
    FOR EACH 'problem' IN 'problems'
        click on the event for the problem
        # The description should begin with "Warning" in red text.
        On the pane below, look for a description of the problem.
        Use the link to understand the problem.
        Use the Call Stack to locate the source of problem.
        Fix it.
    Return "You Did It"

Difficulties: line 14: I wanted to make a recursive call to the strategy, not sure how I could do that, instead wrote it as a statement.
Do While is not in ROBOTO, I decided to follow ROBOTO.
It is hard to draw a line between when to define a Variable, or when to informally mention it in Statements and let the user imply it in the future steps.
Pilot5.StrategyDefinition:
# This strategy helps in using Chrome Profiler to improve your web app
# Required Tools and Environments
Installing Chrome browser
Running your App in Chrome
Opening the developer window, Performance Tab
# Required Knowledge
Knowledge in JavaScript to edit your App
STRATEGY ChromeProfiler()
    # To avoid having tons of data to process, record and process data in small batches
    Start recording in the profiler before event that is running slow
    Perform the actions on the App
    Stop recording
    IF the delay is not observed in the recorded frames
        Restart the strategy with a wider time frame for recording
        RETURN nothing
    # Search for slow frames in the top window of the profiler       
    SET 'slowFrames' TO slowly loaded slowFrames
    FOR EACH 'frame' IN 'slowFrames'
        # frame range is set in the profiler
        set the frame range to the start and end of the CPU usage mountain containing the 'frame'
        # The Flame chart shows the stack of actions and events, by hovering over elements in the stack, the running time will be displayed
        SET 'suspiciousEvents' TO events and actions that take a lot of time in the Flame chart
        FOR EACH 'event' IN 'suspiciousEvents'
            Use the data in the Event Log and Bottom-Up windows in the profiler to find the relevant pieces of code in your App
            check the parts of the code of your App that are responsible in triggering 'event'
            IF you changed anything and guessing it has improved the performance of the App
                DO ChromeProfiler()
                RETURN nothing

Pilot7.ConcentrationDifficulty: I just tried to think of what I would do when I encounter CSS bugs (I am personally not a fan of css) so I try to do out-of-box css whenever possible.
Difficulties: I've learned that browsing through StackOverflow is a key part of debugging any code but it was challenging to write concrete strategies for what developers should be looking for in StackOverflow posts.
Pilot7.GuidelinesSupportDifficulty: Yeah, the tutorial at the beginning comparing good strategy writing and bad strategy writing was useful
Pilot7.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty: It is not that hard to describe the concrete steps they should be taking -- but it is more challenging to list out the questions that they should be asking when they are reading their code
Pilot7.RobotoSupportDifficulty: Yeah, it was useful -- but I didn't actively try to follow the syntax. I only mimicked it.
Pilot7.StrategyDefinition:
# This strategy helps you identify...
# Required tools and environment
Have Node.js installed
Have live-server installed
Have at least 1 html with file with along with some CSS

# Required knowledge
Knowledge of how to work with the terminal and run commands
Reading HTML code
Reading css and adding css to HTML code

STRATEGY DebugCSS()
    Open the terminal and navigate to your project directory where the html files are
    Run `live-server` in the terminal
    IF the command runs and opens a browser tab
        Once you're on the tab, right click
        From the menu select `inspect`. It opens Chrome developer tools
        Make sure you are on the elements tab
        Scroll through the html code and click on the element with faulty behavior
        The bottom half of developer tools now focuses on this element
        On the styles tab, you should see information on what styles were applied and what weren't.
        Identify what styles are overriding the intended CSS
        SET `conflictingCSS TO css classes/ids with conflicts 
        FOR EACH conflict IN conflictingCSS
            DO attemptFix(conflict)
    IF the command produces errors
        Revist the Required Tools and Environment section of this STRATEGY
        Make sure you've installed live-server
    RETURN Nothing


STRATEGY attemptFix()
    Open the html and css code in your favorite code editor
    # id styles take priority over class styles
    IF your CSS does not obey the correct css priority hierarchy
        Redefine the css
    IF css hierarchy looks right
        Do a stackoverflow search describing the problem
        Pick the post that matches your situation
    IF browsing doesn't work
        Look up alternative ways of acheiving the same effect
    RETURN Nothing
Pilot7.StrategyEndingDifficulty: I could enumerate all the possible thinks for certain cases -- looking through StackOverflow for example. I had to leave that step pretty generic which is probably unhelpful.
Pilot7.TimeConsumptionDifficulty: I think it depends on the problem that you're trying to write a strategy for
Pilot7.TranslationDifficulty: Since I wasn't working with a concrete problem it was really challenging to describe a strategy that should in theory help with any CSS problem.

Pilot8.ConcentrationDifficulty: I had to think back to some common use cases for error handling, and when I wrote it I was primarily thinking about forms and authentication. I tried generalizing by specifying if the component is "acting irregularly", but that is a bit broad of a statement.
Pilot8.GuidelinesSupportDifficulty: If it becomes standard and less generalizable and can cover all use cases, I think it can definitely help express strategies.
Pilot8.NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty: I think if you make it granular enough it can be understandable for novice developers but it was difficult to specify the base knowledge of the user for something as general as error handling. Errors often occur with things that are out of the developer's domain knowledge.
Pilot8.RobotoSupportDifficulty: I was not given a reference for how to set variables to the output of a function, so I did "SET X to DO functionName()" instead. I think there could be better ways to express general things. I did "SET 'consoleError' to the error" (error being the error I had the developer locate) for example, which felt like it didn't follow the syntax well.
Pilot8.StrategyDefinition:
# This strategy helps you verify your error handling logic in
# front-end web development

# Preferred Tools and Environments
An integrated development environment with error checking
A component that crashes occasionally for an unknown reason or acts irregularly

# Required/Preferred knowledge
Introductory computer science knowledge (CSE 142 @ UW)
Basic JavaScript knowledge
Try-catch knowledge preferred
Component separation knowledge
Debugger/browser console knowledge

STRATEGY ErrorHandle()
    SET a component-wide global 'errorMessage' to be empty
    # Find the component and function in that component that acts irregularly
    IF the component is acting irregularly or crashing
        SET 'irregularComponent' to the component
        Locate any error messages in the browser's developer console and find the line the error occurs within the 'irregularComponent'
        SET 'irregularComponentFunction' to the function generating this error
        SET 'consoleError' to the error
    IF 'consoleError' is not anything
        RETURN nothing
    ELSE
        # Identifying the reason the line is causing issues can be
        # difficult. It can be a variety of different reasons for your
        # specific use case. 
        SET 'reasonsCrashing' to the reasons the line inside 'irregularComponentFunction' is causing issues by reading the 'consoleError' over
        DO createErrorHandle('reasonCrashing') 
        RETURN nothing

STRATEGY createErrorHandle('reasonCrashing')
    FOR EACH 'reason' in 'reasonCrashing'
        # Create an error handling case
        # It is okay that some errors will take priority
        createErrorHandleCase('reason')
    RETURN nothing

STRATEGY createErrorHandleCase('reason')
    # Most of the time, the reason why it is crashing relates to the
    # user's input, or something you want to share with the user.
    IF 'reason' shows implementation detail
        IF 'reason' was caused by the user's input
            SET 'allErrors' global to be a reason relating to the user's input
        IF 'reason' was caused internally
            SET 'allErrors' to a general "Something went wrong" message 
    ELSE 
        SET 'allErrors' global to the reason why it is crashing
    RETURN nothing
Pilot8.StrategyEndingDifficulty: For something like error handling, you cannot say for sure when all the errors are fixed.
Pilot8.TimeConsumptionDifficulty: It required a lot of thought. I think it is definitely a useful use of my time, and if it were my job to do this, I would have some fun with it but only for brief periods of time. It is sorta like programming. It definitely is time consuming.
Pilot8.TranslationDifficulty: I found it difficult to express what was going through my mind. I was thinking about React because it was a component based framework/library, but I tried to generalize this to anything that uses some sort of component based framework/library. I have been doing error handling for such a long time that it's second nature and difficult to generalize.

CommonDifficulties: TranslationDifficulty: Some strategies are much easier to explain with a short video or demo, especially when demoing a specific tool.

NoviceUnderstandabilityDifficulty : I'm sure that my strategy used knowledge that isn't universally shared (and might be considered an expert blind spot), but, not having a specific instance of this to point to, I'm hopeful that my strategy would be understandable.
ConcentrationDifficulty: I'm confident it could've taken more concentration, effort and energy! It's challenging to anticipate what might go wrong when a novice tries to follow my strategy.

TimeConsumptionDifficulty: It's worthwhile, but I feel that it might be better to provide strategies on-demand, rather than in advance, though this would require a repository of strategies to exist. I think writing a strategy without much context on what the learner needs is challenging.
StrategyEndingDifficulty: A syntactic construct for finishing might be nice here -- it's awkward to return an action "Done"

RobotoSupportDifficulty: Preconditions for using a strategy are a great idea, although it's extremely tempting to just write "basic understanding of x" without specifics of what a basic understanding means. I feel that if a language includes an IF construct, it should also have ELSE and ELSE IF constructs. Programmatic articulation is a good idea, but might be challenging for novices to understand. I've got some concern that some strategies might not express themselves well programmatically, like "try this for a while, if you don't get anywhere in several minutes, try this" or "look at these three examples and determine which one is most intuitive to you"

GuidelinesSupportDifficulty: It's definitely a good way to constrain strategy expression to a format that should be easier to understand than a paragraph of text. Again, I worry that novices, especially those without a good grasp of computation, might struggle with the programmatic format.
OtherDifficulties: I haven't actually done CSS debugging, I had to do some research to understand the typical debugging approach.
It's hard to use text to describe where buttons are (line 11)
There isn't a good way to express "if you got here, I don't know how to help you anymore, go find a different strategy" (line 23)
It's hard to articulate when the strategy was successful or when the strategy failed -- I feel that it should be based in return conditions (line 18, 22, 23)
Articulating "fix the bug" is hard, this definitely feels like a big expert blind spot.
Pilot9.StrategyDefinition:
# This strategy helps in debugging CSS
#Required Tools and Environments
Firefox web browser
#Required Knowledge
Basic understanding of CSS
Understanding of the CSS Cascade (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Cascade)
STRATEGY DebugCss()
    Open file with bug in Firefox
    Right-click on the page and select "Inspect Element"
    Move to the portion of the page with the bug
    To the left of the "Inspector" tab, click the element picker button
    Click the page element that isn't displaying properly
    # The center column of the Inspector shows all styles associated with the element, in order of precedence
    Find the style element that should be shown
    IF the desired style is crossed out
        Find CSS style that overwrote it by scrolling up
        Change the desired style to have higher precedence or the shown style to have lower precedence, or change the inheritance structure
        return done
    IF the desired style isn't shown
        Add the desired style to the project's CSS sheet
        DebugCss()
        return done
    return nothing

pilot1.StrategyDefinition:
# strategy for effectively profiling any React application.

# Required tools and environment
 install React 16.5 or newer
 add DevTools profiler plugin
# Required knowledge
 Basic knowledge of React
 read profiling tool tutorials

 STRATEGY profiling ()
    #open the DevTools
    open the DevTools in a browser
   WHILE you think the performance is fine
        # record the profiler
        start recording profiler
        # first landing page of the application
        open the first page of the application
        # play with most of components of the application for logging
        click or open on most of components of the application in order to be recorded in profiling
        # stop profiler
        in DevTools click stop button
        # watch Component chart
        watch component chart for finding which componets consume more resource like time or memory
        SET 'ComponentNeedProfiling' to the list of components that you watch in the previous step and they consume most of the resource
        FOR EACH 'component' IN 'ComponentNeedProfiling' 
            run flame chart
            ADD 'logsOfFlames' store a log from the output of flame chart for each component
        SORT 'logsOfFlames' sort based on the time consumption or resource, it should be descening
        FIX  watch the flame report and try to fix the first component in the sorted list

Strategy1.ChallengingToWork:
Line # 17: "Change the desired style to have higher precedence or the shown style to have lower precedence, or change the inheritance structure" has 2 branches of action but it is not specified when which condition should be selected and perform. 
Statement "return done" is used to terminate the strategy, but it seems not telling the user if they finished successfully or cannot find the bug.
Strategy1.Clarity: Its clear, but some sentences are a bit confusing at the first step. For instance " Move to the portion of the page with the bug" is a bit confusing what exactly it asked me to do. Maybe using clear keywords helps reducing ambiguity. For instance it can be transcribed as "Navigate to the elements with defective appearance"
Strategy1.Missing: The strategy just works for one defect at a time. For the pages that have more than one defective style feature, the user should rerun the strategy from the beginning. Maybe having a loop to run the strategy on all the defective elements in a list might be helpful
Strategy1.OtherChallenges:
Some strategy statements are very general and have many substeps inside them. Maybe having break the big step to small steps may help easier following the strategy without missing any point. 
The strategy needs a better approach to tell the user if they finished successfully or they should redo the strategy. 
Strategy is not very comprehensive and is just for one defect fixing at a time
Strategy1.requiredInfo: Having a method to keep variables and list.

Strategy2.ChallengingToWork: There are many variables in the strategy that were confusing and hard to follow. For example defining 'irregularComponent' seems redundant.
Strategy2.Clarity: Not in the first glance. Initially I assumed the task is to fix the bugs. So I was looking for fixing statements. Aside that, Still I am not sure why in Strategy createErrorHandleCase the variable allErrors' is getting values, specially when the strategy is returning nothing at the end.
Strategy2.Missing: The type of output from each strategy. It was not clear what is the outcome of each strategy/sub-strategy. Adding that information on top of the strategy as a comment will help.
Strategy2.RequiredInfo: I got lost in the strategy mainly because it was hard to distinguish the comment and the statement specially that the natural language is also used in the statements. Using a different coloring or font helps. The same argument holds for strategy calls and variable names.

Strategy1.ChallengingToWork:
# This Strategy helps impliment error handling for a web application --- But also some stuff about SQLi and databases?
#Considerations
User input
Database Errors 
#Required Knowledge
Web application language
Database SQL
STRATEGY UserInput()
# Goal is to limit free-hand input and use strong typing
Use list-boxes as much as possible   --- What's a list-box?
Use Try-Catch and log errors
IF list-boxes cannot be used, validate textboxes
    Validate datatypes for all enteries
    IF numberic reject alpha  --- It seems like it would be ok here to specify "alphabetical characters". Alpha can also mean a specific symbol, if I'm being nitpicky.
    IF date validate dates and reject invalid dates
    IF character Check for injection (SQL and script) AND   --- How? Probably by parameterizing queries / stored procedures.
       Check for spcial characters   --- Like what? 
    FOR EACH 'textbox' On Page
        Validate
    IF Error Found    
       RETURN Error --- To user? Where?
    ELSE
       Submit Page
STRATEGY Database()
# Handle null values, data truncation, invalid datatypes
In Queries check values before performing Substring functions   --- Check what about the values? Too vague to be helpful for me.
Use stored procedures to limit SQL injection --- Don't just limit SQLi. Prevent it entirely using prepared statements or parameterized queries, which actually can prevent it. Stored procedures do not prevent SQLi by default.
Use IsNull (or NVL) for nulls.  --- Why? In what situation? Does this mean put a string "IsNull" in values that will be null in the database instead of leaving them empty?
Check for blank values using len(trim(<columnName>)) = 0
DO NOT USE "where 1 = 1" in queries as this allows for --- Factually incorrect, see below. 
SQL injection
Use Try-Catch and log all errors --- Where? To console? To an internal error log? To somewhere only developers can see? No consideration for what errors to be logged to the user.
Strategy1.Clarity:
"Use list-boxes as much as possible" -- I don't know what a list box is.
This lacks explanation of why the things in the strategy would be done.
Strategy1.Missing: More detail on what to do, ex. "check" what? Security depth of knowledge is also missing, especially around SQL injection.
Strategy1.OtherChallenges: It is incorrect to state "DO NOT USE "where 1 = 1" in queries as this allows for SQL injection". This DOES NOT allow for SQL injection inherently. "1=1" is a common attack string when testing for SQL injection, but including that as part of a query does not make you any more vulnerable if you have otherwise parameterized your query. source: I am a security engineer...

Strategy2.ChallengingToWork:
I wasn't able to change the background color to a random color using this strategy, since it's CSS specific and I think that would need to happen in the JavaScript to set the CSS. However, this can help narrow down which style piece needs to be adjusted to set a color like that.

I usually inspect elements by clicking on them and then opening the editor. I can't easily right click on the quickly moving boxes-- I need them to be moving slower to click on. Thus, I would not have been able to resolve this if I hadn't gone to look at the source HTML of the page and select an individual box.

Strategy2.RequiredInfo:
This strategy is primarily applicable with Google Chrome. There should be a note on it stating the specific capabilities GC has that allow this strategy to be used. Be explicit about browser capabilities so that it saves people time.

"element.Style" -- this is just setting the style property. It might be useful to say how to do that in a bit more detail, or to say something like style property instead of element.Style.

Pilot2.StrategyDefinition:
#This Strategy helps you identify bottleneck  in your web application.
#Required Tools and Environments
Chrome web browser
A JavaScript project
#Required Knowledge
Basic knowledge of how to use Chrome DevTools
Basic knowledge of javaScript
STRATEGY performanceProfiler()
    # You need to first identify potential line of code
    # that might cause the performance overhead.
    # Look at data structures for any memory leaks
    # Look at loops and the code inside them.
    # Look at third party APIs calls.
Hypothesize where in your code the bottleneck are
Set 'suspectLines' To the line of code that might cause the bottleneck 
For EACH line in 'suspectLines'
    # Add large numbers to data structures
    # Make the loop execute thousands of time
    # Call that third-party API hundreds of time
    # If  you do so, you do not need to execute your code for long time
    # so that the memory leak surfaces or the bottleneck is obvious  
    Amplify line impact
Set 'randomLine' to random line of code that IS NOT IN 'suspectLines'
For EACH line in 'randomLine'
# These lines are your baseline for how should the code work
# Make sure that you set similar values to that 
# you set to 'suspectLine'  
    Amplify line impact
#Lood your javaScript through the Chrome web browser
#Open up the Chrome DevTools and head to the profiler
# Run the application and wait until all the code execute
Run the web application through google DevTools
For EACH line in 'suspectLines'
    #check how the code you suspect is the problem is acting comparing to 
    #the code that you are pretty sure has nothing to do 
    #with the performance issue
    check their CPU time and Memory usage and compare to the similar line in randomLine
    IF the line in 'suspectLines' has more overhead than the line in 'randomLine'
        Fix
RETURN nothing

Difficulties: none
none
Pilot3.StrategyDefinition:
#Required Tools and Environments
Browser Performance Profiler
Performance problem example
#Required Knowledge
Understandinng of memory leaks, CPU performance hotspot, and chart analysis
STRATEGY findPerformanceHotSpot()
    Load web application
    cleare previous recording and start recording performance
    IF perfomance dive is observable at load time
        # perhaps is not CPU related
        observe Network Profiler for unusual load times for app's libraries
    ELSE
       excercise UI to replicate slowdown
       stop recording performance
       IF UI actions triggers slowdown
            go to Performance tab and find frame that matches the slowdown actions
            Find timestamp for action start and end, and narrow down the timeline analysis window
            Look at the Main thread tab and analyze the call stack
            Inspect for unusual calls in the stackframe
            IF unusual call behavior found
                go to responsible code and comment
                repeat this process and compare results
            ELSE
                Inspect Unexpectedly long local calls in the stackframe 
                or Event Log where rendering or function call type activities take more time than expected
                IF unusual rendering behavior found
                    go to responsible code and comment
                    repeat this process and compare results
                    ELSE
                     Try frames before the current one to backtrack the fault and repeat from this STRATEGY from the begining

Difficulties: Depending on example used to devise the strategy, the description may be different. First I was using my own example, which had problems in the top level of the call stack. But, your example has errors deep down the stack, which added more things to look for.
Lack of pictures. The help page you give is much better than what I wrote.
Pilot4.StrategyDefinition:
#Required tools and environment
Chrome/Chromium Browser
#Required knowledge
HTML tags
JS/CSS proficiency: professional
STRATEGY Profile()
    Open the webpage that you want to profile.
    Open DevTools and navigate to the Performance tab.
    Comprehend the actions you want to profile.
    IF you want to only profile the page load time
        Click on the "Start Profiling and reload page" button.
        # Profiling will stop few seconds after page load.
        Wait for profiling to finish.
    ELSE
        Click on the "Start Profiling button"
        Perform your actions and click "Stop" when done
    # Each event is a rectangle box. Scrolling should zoom in and out
    Observe that the profiler produces a graph of events captured
    # Top right red corners indicate events with potential performance issues
    SET 'problems' TO events with red top right corners 
    FOR EACH 'problem' IN 'problems'
        click on the event for the problem
        # The description should begin with "Warning" in red text.
        On the pane below, look for a description of the problem.
        IF description is not helpful
            # Use the child events to drill deep into the stack
            Click on the red events below the current event. 
        Use the link to understand the problem.
        Use the Call Stack to locate the source of problem.
        Fix it.
    Return "You Did It"

ChallengingToWork.AspectForgotten: It's a broad problem with language as a whole, but it was challenging to anticipate how my words would be read. If I had uncertainty when writing a strategy, it's almost certain that whoever read my strategy would also feel uncertain.
ChallengingToWork.HardAddressing: I don't know if it'd be particularly hard to address, but I worry about making the strategy too long. I feel like, similar with functions, it's useful to have modularity and succinctness, and I may struggle to maintain that when addressing the comment.
ChallengingToWork.MakeSense: It does! I struggled to express the specifics of that action into a strategy, so it ended up being too much information for a single line. I also could have used "return success" or "return failure" in my strategy, instead of "return done".

Clarity.AspectForgotten: Again, considering many possible interpretations of my language. It's easier when writing a programming language -- there's a shared context in keywords, but since most of Roboto isn't keywords, it's hard to define a shared context between the writer and the reader. I think that writing in a programming language-esq syntax primes me to write with brevity over clarity, since I can always append with comments instead of writing long-form prose, which might make a better strategy description (and it'd be good to do the comparison).
Clarity.HardAddressing: It takes substantial effort to write a really good, concise, well-written strategies!
Clarity.MakeSense: It does! Again, I totally understand that the language that I choose to use might have a different interpretation or clarity when read.

Missing.AspectForgotten: It's challenging to have the entire problem domain in my head at once when writing a strategy. There's probably a cognitive load/working-memory argument for why writing strategies is hard.
Missing.HardAddressing: This is easy to address, I just didn't think to address it when I was writing the strategy.
Missing.MakeSense: It does! Tester1 recognizes a part of the problem domain that I didn't consider when writing the strategy.

OtherChallenges.AspectForgotten: I forgot to consider how to make the strategy comprehensive, I also didn't consider how many ways my language would be interpreted and how long steps are hard to parse.
OtherChallenges.HardAddressing: Again, it'd just be effort to write a really really good strategy. There's a lot of care that should be taken with language that I didn't put as much effort into.
OtherChallenges.MakeSense: Yes! It encapsulates many of the other comments that were given -- my strategy encapsulated too much inside a single step and didn't take care of the case of multiple bugs.

RequiredInfo.AspectForgotten: This question isn't super relevant to a single word response.
RequiredInfo.HardAddressing: It's hard to address a comment that I don't understand!
RequiredInfo.MakeSense: This one doesn't -- it's hard to glean meaning from a single word.
